params.text:
INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT

Pest is managed by using various methods or tactics to minimize the use of chemical pesticides is called integrated pest management (IPM). IPM methods are cultural, physical, mechanical, biological, and policy and quarantine regulations. Regular monitoring of the condition of the crop is a key to successful pest management. Knowledge on the pests is important to identify what method is the best to use.

Insect Pest Management

The common insect pests of eggplant and growth stage of infestation and the control measures is as follows:

 

The insect pests of eggplant, damage and control method.

items.description:
Ants

 

DAMAGE/HARM

It will result to missing hills, uneven growth, low of crop stand, and an increased incidence of diseases caused by the insect pests.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Control aphids, whitefly and other insects that excrete honeydew. 

  • Spray mixture of dishwashing soap, vegetable oil, table salt, vinegar and water. 

  • Cultivate and flood the field. 

  • Avoid too much application of nitrogen fertilizer.

  • Remove the infested plant part immediately.

Aphids

(Aphis gossypii)

 

DAMAGE/HARM

  • Nymphs and adults feed on plant sap.

  • Plants will defoliate and have stunted growth. 

  • Distorted leaves.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Place yellow sticky traps on planting area. 

  • Place yellow basin trap on the area. 

  • Use botanical pesticides such as ginger rhizome extract and custard apple leaf extract. 

  • Spray soap mixed with water (coconut-based soap). 

  • Spray ammonia mixed with water.

Colorado Potato Beetle (Leptinotarsa decemlineata)

 

DAMAGE/HARM

Adults and larvae feed on young and soft leaves and often consume the entire part.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Practice crop rotation.

  • Remove weeds. 

  • Plow-under crop residues after harvest. 

  • Crush eggs and collect adults manually. 

  • Use row covers. 

  • Mulching to provide habitat for beneficial insects.

Cutworm

(Spodoptera litura)

 

DAMAGE/HARM

  • Young caterpillars eat the soft leaves of the plant. 

  • Fully grown caterpillars can the entire plant if not managed immediately. 

  • Newly hatched larvae feed from the base towards the leaf tip. 

  • Infested leaves have discoloration and yellow color.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Remove the weeds at 2-3 weeks after planting.  

  • Plow and harrow fields properly before planting. 

  • Interplant main crops with onion, garlic, coriander, or garlic every 10-20 rows. 

  • Plant trap crop. 

  • Place sticky substances.

Fruit and Shoot Borer

(Leucinodes orbonalis)

 

DAMAGE/HARM

  • Infested parts are wilted shoots, small holes in shoot and fruit.

  • It bores into the young fruit and feeds inside, hence, unmarketable.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Plow the field to expose larvae to predators and weather. 

  • Plant resistant varieties. 

  • Practice crop rotation. 

  • Proper sanitation. 

  • Cut and/or prune immediately the larvae-infested shoots and burn. 

  • Use pheromone traps.

Spider Mites

 

DAMAGE/HARM

  • Feeds on the undersides of leaves which turn to yellow color, dry up, and drop in a few weeks. 

  • The upper leaf surface has a speckled or mottled appearance while the underneath appears tan or yellow and has a crusty texture. 

  • Heavy infested leaf has fine cobweb appearance and may die.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Spray botanical pesticides like Coriander seed extract.

  • Remove infested plant part.

  • Spray insecticide if needed.

Stink bug

 

DAMAGE/HARM

  • Damage parts are leaves, flowers, bolls, buds, fruits, and seeds.

  • Destructive stages are adults and nymphs. 

  • Damaged fruits have scarring and dimpling known as cat-facing.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Remove weeds in the field and adjacent fields.  

  • Plow-under all plant debris.

  • Use parasitoids such as native parasitic wasps on the area.

Thrips

 

DAMAGE/HARM

  • They suck up the released plant fluid. 

  • Damages are tiny scars on leaves and fruit or stippling, stunted growth; papery and distorted leaves; and infested terminals, leaf discoloration, leaf rolling, and drop leaves prematurely.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Spray botanical pesticides such as garlic bulb extract. 

  • Spray insecticide if needed.

Whiteflies

 

DAMAGE/HARM

  • Larvae and adults pierce and suck the sap of the leaves. 

  • Damages are yellowing, drying, and premature dropping of leaves.

  • Severed damage may cause plant death due to weakening and wilting. 

  • Poor plant growth of due to molds. Honeydews secreted by whiteflies serve as the substrates for the growth of black sooty molds on leaves and fruit.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Spray botanical pesticides such as garlic oil extract, madre de cacao and neem extract, and neem oil extract. 

  • Spray soap (coconut-based). 

  • Spray potato flour mixed with water and drops of liquid soap.

  • Spray insecticide if needed.

params.text:
Insect pest of eggplant and growth stage of infestation.
 
Growth Stages          Insects/Mites
0 Stage              
     - Seed              - Ants
Seedling Stage              
     - Leaves              - Aphids
               - Whiteflies
Vegetative Stage  
       - Leaves              - Aphids
               - Colorado potato beetle
               - Flea beetle (Epitrix fuscula)
               - Spider Mites
               - Thrips
               - Whiteflies
               - Eggplant fruit and shoot borer
Reproductive/Flowering Stage  
       - Flowers and foliage              - Aphids
       - Stem              - Colorado potato beetle
               - Flea beetle
               - Spider Mites
               - Stink bugs
               - Thrips
               - Whiteflies
               - Eggplant fruit and shoot borer
Maturation/ Fruiting Stage  
        - Flowers and stems              - Eggplant fruit and shoot borer

DISEASE MANAGEMENT

          Regular monitoring of the field is done to assess if the crops are experiencing nutrient deficiency, drought stress, infestation or infection. The common diseases of eggplant and its control methods are:

The common diseases of eggplant, damage and control method.

items.description:
DISEASE: Bacterial Wilt

 

DAMAGE

  • Causal organism is bacteria scientifically known as Ralstonia (Pseudomona) solanacearum).

  • Wilting of the terminal leaves. If not managed immediately, the whole plant wilts due to the active

  • disease development, hence, sudden death of whole plant. 

  • There is slow disease development if the plant has stunted growth and the plant has large numbers of adventitious roots on the stem.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Remove and destroy infected plants immediately. 

  • Practice crop rotation. 

  • Heat sterilizes the farm tools before using them in another field.

DISEASE: Damping-off

 

DAMAGE

  • The fungal disease caused by Rhizoctonia solani

  • Dark-brown to black water-soaked lesions that rapidly spread over the entire seedling causing the seedling to wilt and die (Pythium spp.). 

  • Lesions are also found on roots and stem near the soil line that cause the seedlings to wilt and eventually die.  

  • Dark-brown or reddish brown lesions on the stem and dark-brown lesions on roots and stems at or near the crown which may kill the seedlings.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Improve drainage and regulate soil moisture to prevent soil saturation. 

  • Seed treatment. 

  • Crop rotation to cereal crops. 

  • Soil fumigation or solarization.

DISEASE: Verticillium Wilt

 

DAMAGE

  • Caused by the fungi Verticillium albo-atrum

  • Initial symptom is yellowing of the leaf margins which later turn brown and cause the plant to wilt. 

  • Stunted and wilted plants.

  • The lengthwise cut of the infected stem has dark-brown discoloration in the vascular tissue.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Practice crop rotation with non-solanaceous crops.

  • Grafted eggplant. 

  • Use verticilium wilt resistant varieties.

DISEASE: Phytophthora Blight

 

DAMAGE

  • It is caused by fungus Pytopthora parasitica, which is common during rainy season. Fruits near or in contact with the soil become readily infected.

  • Symptoms are dark-brown spots, water-soaked with a light-colored border which expands rapidly and can cover mature fruits in 3 to 4 days.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Good water management. 

  • Avoid stagnant water on the base of the plants.

  • Provide good soil drainage. 

  • Avoid movement of infested soil, water, and plant parts from an area where Phytophthora rot has developed. 

  • Plant resistant variety.

DISEASE: Phomopsis

 

DAMAGE

  • Caused by a fungus, Phomopsis vexan which is seed borne. 

  • The infected fruit has circular brown spots with numerous black fruiting bodies of the fungus appear on the leaves.

 

CONTROL METHOD

  • Destroy infected plant material.

  • Plant resistant varieties and use non-infected seedlings. 

  • Crop rotation (3-4 years). 

  • Observe sanitation. 

  • Apply fungicide in combination with the above cultural practices.

params.text:
WEED MANAGEMENT

Weeds are major competitors of a crop in the uptake of nutrients, water, light and carbon dioxide. They also serve as alternate host to a range of pests and diseases affecting eggplant. Remove weeds either by manual weeding or chemical application (if necessary) from transplanting to early fruiting stage. Weeds can be removed manually and done when these have three to four leaves.
